--0-1742087540-1225737350=:94858
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I work with a number of manufacturing companies and often see a great deal of inefficiency in their processes. I have also struggled with PCB design programs and see that they are screaming for a good CPPN introduction. The process appears simple and trivial, but there is a great deal of intelligence behind a good PCB design. 

I have no skill with Dr Stanley's model, but see it strengths in many ways. I was hoping this topic would prompt someone to see this as a viable challenge and produce something. 

Sent from my iPhone

On Nov 1, 2008, at 2:44 PM, kelly parker <bigblockfw@...> wrote:

Thinking a bit more along the same path (pun intended) would be G code optimization.
I don't know if you've ever watched a cnc mill wander around waisting time but it's expensive 
if you're mass producing something like PCBs.
The less time it takes the tool to get to it's next "job" the more efficient the manufacturing process is. I've always had to do that by hand (or just start the machine and go take a nap) but it would be a good place to start. If the software can route traces but not tool paths....well, that just seems goofy. 
Some of the "lessons learned" from tool path routing could potentially apply to trace routing and be a comparatively easy milestone for the real holy grail.







--- On Fri, 10/31/08, kelly parker <bigblockfw@...> wrote:
From: kelly parker <bigblockfw@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Another use
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, October 31, 2008, 6:01 PM

Let me know when it's ready :-)

I was thinking along similar lines the other day.
The beagle board...
  http://beagleboard. org/
is a great little gadget but it's only useful as a "demo" board for that incredible chip.
If you want to do something/anything different your in for a massive headache.
Inserting some "intelligence" into the auto-router would be HUGE.

Seriously, if you could pull that off you would be a hero to EE types everywhere.



--- On Thu, 10/30/08, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@cs. utexas.edu> wrote:
From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@cs. utexas.edu>
Subject: [neat] Re: Another use
To: neat@yahoogroups. com
Date: Thursday, October 30, 2008, 10:07 PM

--- In neat@yahoogroups. com, Erikcss <erikcss@... > wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
> This idea steps a little outside the normal use of CPPN's, but I
think it would make for an interesting use. 
> 
> Having worked with a number of circuitry part placement and routing
programs, I have seen a lot of room for improvement. Considering the
nature of the problem and operation of CPPNs, I think evolving a CPPN
to place and route traces would be pretty effective and useful. Do you
know if anyone has tried to use a CPPN for this purpose?
>

I've never heard of any work using CPPNs for that purpose. What are
the main issues in placing and routing traces? That's not my area but
I am interested in how you imagine CPPNs could be applied.

ken
